In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function `wrap_string` to wrap a string at a given text width by splitting the original string into parts and joining them with newline characters when necessary. Here's how you can implement this function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    # Split the text into an array of words
    lines = split(text)
    wrapped_lines = Vector{String}() # Empty vector to store wrapped lines

    for line in lines
        if length(line) > text_width
            # If a word is longer than the text width, add it as is
            push!(wrapped_lines, line)
        else
            # Otherwise, accumulate words until the limit is reached or all words are added
            acc = ""
            for w in line
                if length(acc) + length(w) <= text_width
                    acc *= w * " "
                else
                    push!(wrapped_lines, acc)
                    acc = ""
                end
            end
            # Add the remaining words from this line
            if acc â‰  ""
                push!(wrapped_lines, acc)
            end
        end
    end

    return join(wrapped_lines, "\n") # Join wrapped lines with newline characters
end
```

This function takes a `text::AbstractString` and an optional `text_width::Int`. It splits the text into words using `split` and then iterates over each word, adding them to a vector of strings. When a word exceeds the specified text width, it is added as a new line in the vector. Otherwise, it is appended to the current line being built.
